gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: National Coral Reef Monitoring Program: Structure from motion (SfM) Benthic Images collected at the Fixed Site [*SiteName*] around [*IslandName*] in [*Region*] on [*SurveyDate*]

gmd:alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: SfM [*Region*] [*Year*] Vital Rates Benthic Imagery at Fixed Sites ([*parent metadata ID*])

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Pacific Island Fisheries Science Center homepage

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This archival package contains imagery from [*SiteName*] that was obtained around [*IslandName*] on [*SurveyDate*].
The photographs described in this dataset were collected using a Structure from Motion (SfM) approach during in-water surveys throughout the U.S. Pacific since 2019. Surveys were funded by NOAA Coral Reef Conservation Program (CRCP) and conducted by the NOAA Fisheries, Ecosystem Sciences Division (ESD). Survey sites consisted of sites previously established by collaborators from Scripps Institution of Oceanography and new sites established in 2019 by NOAA ESD. All sites ranged from 9-16 meters in depth and surveys covered approximately 100 m2 of reef habitat.
Sites were photographed by divers swimming approximately 1 m off the seafloor with high overlap between images to produce SfM products. The data extracted from this imagery provides information on juvenile and adult taxonomic identification, abundance, planar area across the [*Region*] in [*Year*], and can be used to track the fate of individual coral colonies over time. This data is archived separately within NCEI.
This archival package contains imagery from [*SiteName*] that was obtained around [*IslandName*] on [*SurveyDate*].

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Raw imagery collected at each site was later processed using a structure from motion (SfM) approach to create 3-dimensional (3D) models and 2-dimensional (2D) orthorectified images. The purpose of the SfM surveys of permanent sites throughout the U.S. Pacific is to track coral vital rates (e.g. growth, mortality, recruitment) and how they vary across taxon, regions, and environmental gradients. This study leveraged SfM, an emerging photogrammetry technique, to allow efficient data collection alongside NCRMP essential efforts.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: NOAA Fisheries, Ecosystem Sciences Division and funded by the NOAA Ocean Acidification Program

NOAA and NCEI cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in these data. If appropriate, NCEI can only certify that the data it distributes are an authentic copy of the records that were accepted for inclusion in the NCEI archives.

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Cite this imagery by using the citation from the yearly NCRMP regional mission. Follow the link to the NCRMP regional mission landing page under the Documentation tab for the citation text.

gmd:environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: A GPS unit was used to record the location of each Structure from Motion (SfM) survey site. Coded markers 25cm in length were used underwater to provide a scale for the mosaic imagery. A digital camera in an underwater housing was used to take photographs of each site.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: DOC/NOAA/NESDIS/NCEI > National Centers for Environmental Information, NESDIS, NOAA, U.S. Department of Commerce

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information website

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Main NCEI website providing links to access data and data services.
This URL provides a standard HTTP interface for selecting data from this dataset. The transfer size is in mb.

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: The data set derived from the imagery is only as good as the images themselves; Images with poor resolution, poor lighting, extraneous objects (fins, etc), or blur were excluded from analysis.

Prior to conducting surveys, the SfM image collector was trained to swim in either a crosshatch or spiral pattern with at least two passes to collect imagery with 60-80% overlap. Both classroom and field training were completed before any surveys were conducted. This training ensures that all SfM image collection was conducted consistently during each mission.
Handheld GPS units, stainless steel rods affixed to the benthos, and representative site photos were used to locate reef area that had been previously surveyed and mark new site locations.

SfM imagery was collected [*Region*] on [*SurveyDate*]. All sites were between 9-16m deep and and covered approximately 100 m2 of reef. Images that were blurred or had unnecessary objects (e.g., dive fins) were removed. Depending on the location surveys are repeated at time intervals from several hours to 3 years.
The same method of image collection was used at each surveyed site.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Fixed site SfM surveys have been conducted by the Pacific Islands Fisheries Science Center's Ecosystem Sciences Division (ESD) since 2019 and Scripps Institution of Oceanography since 2013.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString:
Fixed sites used by NOAA ESD for SfM surveys have been established in a site-dependent manner using multiple types of physical marking configurations. In this dataset, fixed sites were either established using physical markers already existing within NCRMP climate stations or were established by collaborators at Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
To set up the survey area, at least two Ground Control Points (GCPs) of known length with Agisoft patterns at both ends are placed 2-3 meters away from the center of the survey area opposite of each other and rebar caps with Agisoft patterns affixed to the top are placed on top of the stainless-steel rods (rebar caps not used in every survey). Using a datasheet, a rough sketch of the survey area, including the location and marker number of each GCP and rebar cap, the depth of each GCP, and the latitude and longitude of the center of the survey area are recorded prior to beginning each survey. As one diver completed the datasheet, the other diver color balanced a Nikon SL2 or SL3 DSLR digital camera in an Ikelite underwater housing using a 18% gray card.

Imagery was collected in a circular or crosshatch pattern at a slow, sustainable speed 1 meter off the bottom of the reef while continuously capturing jpg images to achieve 60-80% image overlap. Divers collected imager approximately 2 m past the 10 m diameter of the plot and conducted two full passes of the survey site to further improve image overlap and ensure the site was fully surveyed.

Images for each site were evaluated to remove extraneous or erroneous photographs (e.g. fins, blue water, excessive blur, etc.). Sites with imagery that was not white balanced, were consistently overexposed or excessively dark were color corrected using Adobe Lightroom. Image adjustments were batch run per site for consistent correction.
Image data includes ~3500 benthic photographs per survey site. Included in the archive package is a list of survey sites, including region, island, site, date (day, month, year), latitude (dd), longitude (dd), depth marker numbers with corresponding depth values, marker length for scaling models, camera model and lens focal length, if the images for a site were color or exposure corrected and a unique image name. The file naming convention for each image is NCRMP_SFM_FIXED_YEAR_MissionID_REGION_ISLAND_SITENAME_IMG_####.jpg.

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: This ISO metadata record was programmatically generated.
